title: L'Estaque

thumbnail.alt_text: Painting of coastal town seen through leafy branches, blue sea and sky fill background.

description:
Émilie Charmy was among the first women to exhibit paintings in the Fauvist style. Traveling to rugged sites on France’s Mediterranean coast, such as L’Estaque, depicted here, she created landscapes suffused with emotion and subjective expression. Laying down vibrant color in broad unstructured planes, she composed the scene as a collection of loosely joined organic forms. The swelling and tapering shapes along the composition’s edges produce a dynamic sense of movement that dissipates at the center, where we glimpse the calm waters of the Bay of Marseille.

Charmy was celebrated during her lifetime, but the accolades she received feel wildly gendered today. In 1921, for example, a French writer described her as an artist who “sees like a woman and paints like a man…from the one she takes grace and from the other strength, and this is what makes her such a strange and powerful painter who holds our attention.”
publication_history:
Association of American Painters and Sculptors, International Exhibition of Modern Art, exh. cat. (New York: Association of American Painters and Sculptors, 1913), n.p., cat. 170, as Paysage. 

Association of American Painters and Sculptors, International Exhibition of Modern Art, exh. cat. (Chicago version, 1913), n.p., cat. 64, as Landscape. 

Eddy, Arthur Jerome, Cubists and Post-Impressionism (Chicago: A.C. McClurg & Co., 1914), pp. n.p., 200, opp. 200 (ill.), as Landscape. 

Art Institute, Exhibition of Paintings from the Collection of the Late Arthur Jerome Eddy, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute, 1922), n.p., cat. 14, as L’Estaque.

Art Institute, The Arthur Jerome Eddy Collection of Modern Paintings and Sculpture, exh. cat. (Chicago: Art Institute, 1931), pp. 8, cat. 2, 10, as Landscape: L’Estaque, c. 1910.

Bulliet, C.J., “The Eddy Gift to Chicago,” Creative Art 10, 3 (March 1932), p. 216, as Landscape.

Paintings in the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute, 1961), p. 76, as L’Estaque, c. 1910. 

Association of American Painters and Sculptors, The Armory Show: International Exhibition of Modern Art, vol. 3, Contemporary and Retrospective Documents (New York: Arno Press, 1972), n.p. (ill.). 

Speyer, A. James and Courtney Graham Donnell, Twentieth-Century European Paintings (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1980), p. 36, no. 1D5, as L’Estaque, c. 1910. 

Brown, Milton, The Story of the Armory Show (New York: Abbeville Press, 1988), p. 255, no. 170, as Landscape, now called L’Estaque, c. 1910. 

The Arts Club of Chicago, Émilie Charmy [Brochure] (The Arts Club of Chicago, 2014), pp. 4, 5, cat. 9, as L'Estaque, c. 1910.
exhibition_history:
Possibly Paris, Galerie E. Druet, Exposition de peintures de Émilie Charmy, January 29–February 11, 1911.

Association of American Painters and Sculptors (organizer), International Exhibition of Modern Art; traveled to New York, Armory of the 69th Infantry, February 17–March 15, 1913, n.p. (cat. 170), as Paysage; Chicago, Art Institute, March 24–April 16, 1913, n.p. (cat. 64), as Landscape; and Boston, Copley Society Hall, April 28–May 19, 1913 [New York and Chicago only].

Chicago, Art Institute, Exhibition of Paintings from the Collection of the Late Arthur Jerome Eddy, September 19–October 22, 1922, n.p., cat. 14, as L’Estaque.

Chicago, The Arthur Jerome Eddy Collection of Modern Paintings and Sculpture, December 22, 1931–January 17, 1932, pp. 8, cat. 2, 10, as Landscape: L’Estaque, c. 1910. 

Chicago, Englewood High School, May–June 1948. 

Chicago, Arts Club of Chicago, Émilie Charmy, February 27–May 17, 2014, pp. 4, 5, cat. 9, as L'Estaque, c. 1910.
provenance_text: Druet, Paris, by 1913 [copy of letter from Treasurer of the Association of American Painters and Sculptors to M. E. Druet, May 2, 1913, Walter Kuhn Papers, Archives of American Art, Series 1, Subseries 1.6]; sold to Arthur Jerome Eddy (1859-1920), Chicago, March 1913 [Brown 1988]; by descent to his wife Lucy O. Eddy (1863-1931) and son Jerome O. Eddy (1891-1951), Chicago, 1920; given to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1931.
